what is somnia?:
Somnia is an EVM based layer 1 blockchain. It is noted for its fast speed. It is capable of processing over 1,000,000 transactions per second (TPS) with sub-second finality and is suitable for serving millions of users and building real-time, fully on-chain mass-consumer applications like games, social applications, metaverses, etc. 
 https://docs.somnia.network 
 https://blog.somnia.network

what is the use case for somnia token?:
Being a lightning fast blockchain with the potential for over 1,000,000 transactions every second, the Somnia chain has a use case in building deFi, gaming, metaverse, social, and Real World Asset (RWA) decentralized applications. The somnia token, $SOMI will act as the standard currency to leverage the somnia chain for these applications. Other than these, the $SOMI token also would be usable for the other operations that fungible tokens support, like staking, transfer, swaps, and so on. Additionally, $SOMI is a delegated proof of stake token (dPoS) it is intended for: 
 1. Staking functions 
 Validator staking - To provide validator nodes for the Somnia blockchain, Tokens must be staked. 
 Delegated staking - Tokens can be delegated to Node Providers to cover their staking costs. 
 2. Payment methods 
 Gas Fees - To use the blockchain, gas fees will be paid in the SOMI token. 
 3. Governance: The Token will eventually be used to inform how decisions regarding the Network and its components are made. The details of this are to be determined.
what is the somnia token distribution?:

Only 20% of the allocated community airdrop tokens are released at TGE, with the remaining 80% released over 60 days after the mainnet launch, contingent on users completing specific tasks. Any unclaimed tokens from the airdrop after the 90-day window will be returned to an ecological fund for future ecosystem growth and incentives. The detailed token distribution can be found here: 
 https://docs.somnia.network/concepts/tokenomics/allocation-and-unlocks

how do i develop on the somnia blockchai:
Being an EVM chain, development on Somnia is similar to that on any other EVM chain like Arbitrum or Sei, or even Ethereum. You will need a wallet that supports EVM chains, for example MetaMask, and have the required test tokens to be able to deploy on the Somnia Testnet. You can use the Remix IDE to write the smart contracts online, in the browser itself. 
 https://docs.somnia.network/developer/resources-and-important-links#ide 
 You can check out the tutorials here: 
 https://docs.somnia.network/developer/tutorials

how can i deploy a smart contract on som:
Being an EVM chain, development on Somnia is similar to that on any other EVM chain like Arbitrum or Sei, or even Ethereum. The contracts are in Solidity, similar to the chains mentioned. You will need a wallet that supports EVM chains, for example MetaMask, and have the required test tokens to be able to deploy on the Somnia Testnet. You can use the Remix IDE to write the smart contracts online, in the browser itself. Once the code is written, use the compile option followed by the deploy option. Make sure you are connected to your wallet on the right network (Somnia Testnet) while invoking the deploy function. 
 https://docs.somnia.network/developer/resources-and-important-links#ide 
 You can check out the tutorials here: 
 https://docs.somnia.network/developer/tutorials 
 https://testnet.somnia.network
what programming languages does somnia s: Being an EVM based Layer 1, Somnia supports Solidity. Any smart contract written for Ethereum, Polygon, Arbitrum, etc in Solidity can be deployed to Somnia as well.
how is gas fee on somnia:
Somnia’s model follows Ethereum’s structure: Total Fee = Gas Usage x Gas Unit Price 
 Gas Usage 
 Total gas units consumed by a transaction, determined by the following formula: 
Gas Usage = Base Gas + Transaction Data + Opcodes. 
 https://docs.somnia.network/concepts/tokenomics/gas-fees
how secure is somnia:
Somnia is an EVM-compatible Layer 1 blockchain designed for high-performance applications, and its security model is built around a Proof-of-Stake (PoS) consensus mechanism with a MultiStream protocol. Here are key aspects of its security: 
 1. Proof-of-Stake with Slashing: Somnia uses a PoS system where validators stake tokens to participate in network consensus. Malicious behavior, such as double-signing or downtime, results in slashing penalties, aligning validator incentives with network security. 
 2. MultiStream Consensus: This protocol, inspired by Autobahn BFT, separates data production from consensus. Validators operate independent data chains, while a separate consensus chain ensures global transaction ordering using a modified Practical Byzantine Fault Tolerance (PBFT) algorithm. This reduces vulnerabilities by isolating consensus processes. 
 3. Sufficient Decentralization: Somnia prioritizes 'sufficient' rather than maximal decentralization to balance security and performance. It initially operates with 100 globally distributed validator nodes, with plans to expand as the network matures. Hardware requirements are set between Solana and Aptos node specs to ensure robust participation without compromising performance. 
 4. Advanced Cryptographic Techniques: Posts on X suggest Somnia employs advanced cryptographic protocols like homomorphic encryption and multi-party computation (MPC) for secure data handling, though these claims require further verification. 
 5. CertiK Monitoring: Somnia is tracked by CertiK’s Skynet for security audits, on-chain monitoring, and bug bounties, indicating proactive security measures. 
 6. Immutable Transactions: The network ensures tamper-proof transactions, enhancing security through immutability and transparency. 
 While Somnia’s architecture emphasizes security, its long-term track record is still developing, as it remains in the testnet phase. Investors and developers should monitor validator decentralization and real-world stress tests for a complete assessment.

what is somnia's roadmap?:
Somnia’s roadmap is not fully detailed in public sources, but available information outlines key milestones and ongoing efforts: 
 Testnet Phase (Ongoing): Somnia launched its Shannon Testnet on February 20, 2025, following DevNet benchmarks that achieved over 1 million transactions per second (TPS). The testnet focuses on scalability, third-party validator integration, and staking protocols to enhance decentralization. It has processed over 3.6 million transactions across 300,000+ unique addresses. 
 Mainnet Launch (2025): Somnia is gearing up for its mainnet launch later in 2025, though no specific date is confirmed. The mainnet will support fully on-chain applications, including gaming, DeFi, and metaverse platforms. 
    Ecosystem Expansion: Somnia has introduced 14 decentralized applications (dApps) on its testnet, covering DeFi, gaming, AI, and metaverse use cases. Projects like Chunked (a sandbox MMO) and Sparkball (a multiplayer sports game) are driving transaction volume. A $10 million ecosystem grant program supports developer engagement. 
    Developer Tools and Interoperability: Somnia is focusing on low-code tools like Somnia Builder and omnichain protocols to enable seamless asset transfers across blockchains. It aims to unify gaming, metaverse, and NFT ecosystems into a 'Virtual Society'. 
    Community Engagement: Initiatives like Galxe campaigns, daily check-ins, and a potential airdrop for testnet participants are part of Somnia’s strategy to attract 1 million users to stress-test the network. 
    Future Goals: Somnia aims to support real-time, data-intensive applications at scale, with a focus on gaming and social platforms. Long-term, it seeks to establish a decentralized creator economy with interoperable digital assets. 
    The roadmap emphasizes scalability, developer adoption, and ecosystem growth, but specific timelines beyond the mainnet launch are unclear. Please follow the official channels like Somnia’s Discord or X account for more updates on this.
Key members of the Somnia Network team include: Paul Thomas (Founder)
 Michelle Kang (CMO)
 Sal Liberto Jr (Head of Business Development)
 You can find their details here: 
 https://cryptorank.io/price/somnia/team
how can i earn rewards on somnia?: Currently, there is no such campaign. Users are encouraged to do the testnet tasks like swaps and NFT purchase, but there is no guarantee that these will be used as a criterion while distributing airdrop rewards to the community.
what is awesom ai?: Awesom AI is a Somnia-centric AI Agent. Known for its vast collection of cached and free queries, it aims to be the one stop solution for all Somnia-related queries. It is maintained by the Resurgence Labs team.
how does awesom ai work?: Awesom AI enables the user to submit info, transactional, and custom queries. The info queries are cached and maintained by continuous scraping of the Somnia ecosystem, while the custom queries make an additional call to an AI backend.
what can i do with awesom ai?: You can have your queries about the Somnia Network answered with Awesom AI. You can receive a basic tutotial for development on Somnia. You can also complete transactions like sending testnet $STT tokens and swaps using it. You can also complete custom queries using an integrated AI backend.
can awesom ai be used for defi actions?: Yes. Awesom AI can be used to complete de-fi actions like swapping and transfer of funds. However, this ultimately makes a wallet call on your behalf and the transaction can be completed only after you have signed it. Therefore, please evaluate the transaction details before signing. For more details, please read the Awesom AI docs.
how many transactions happen daily on so:
Somnia’s transaction volume is primarily reported from its testnet phase, as the mainnet is not yet live. Available data highlights: 
    Peak Performance: Somnia’s testnet achieved a record of 80 million transactions in a single day, driven largely by the sandbox MMO game Chunked, which alone generated 250 million transactions over a week with over 70,000 concurrent users. 
    Testnet Activity: The Shannon Testnet has processed over 3.6 million transactions across 300,000+ unique addresses, but daily averages are not consistently reported. The 80 million transaction peak is an outlier tied to specific testnet activities. 
    Network Capacity: Somnia claims a capacity of over 1 million TPS, with sub-second finality and sub-cent fees, demonstrated in DevNet benchmarks. However, real-world daily transaction volumes depend on user activity and dApp adoption, which are still scaling.
    Comparison: The 80 million daily transactions surpass Ethereum’s peak of 1.9 million and Solana’s peak of 66.9 million, though these figures reflect testnet conditions, not sustained mainnet performance.
    Since Somnia is in testnet, daily transaction volumes fluctuate based on testing activities and are not representative of mainnet performance. Once the mainnet launches, consistent daily metrics will depend on adoption and use cases like gaming and DeFi. For the latest data, users should check Somnia’s official analytics or testnet dashboards.

how does somnia's omnichain interoperabi: Somnia’s omnichain interoperability enables seamless asset and data transfers across EVM and non-EVM blockchains using a decentralized bridge protocol. Built on its MultiStream architecture, it leverages cross-chain messaging and standardized token wrappers to facilitate transfers. Validators secure the bridge by attesting to state changes, ensuring trustless communication. The Somnia Builder tool simplifies integration for developers, supporting interoperable dApps in gaming and DeFi. Testnet demos show NFT and token bridging, but mainnet scalability and bridge security (e.g., against double-spend attacks) await real-world validation. Limitations include potential latency and reliance on validator consensus.
how does somnia's multistream consensus: Somnia’s MultiStream protocol uses a modified PBFT algorithm, ensuring consensus even if up to one-third of validators are offline or partitioned. Data chains operate independently, and the consensus chain maintains global ordering, minimizing disruption. Recovery mechanisms prioritize validator resync with minimal latency.
what are the specific hardware specs for: Somnia validator nodes require hardware between Solana and Aptos specs: approximately 16-core CPU, 64GB RAM, 1TB NVMe SSD, and 1Gbps network bandwidth. Exact requirements may adjust post-mainnet, balancing accessibility and performance for 100+ global nodes.
how does somnia's testnet handle spam tr: Somnia’s testnet mitigates spam through rate-limiting and gas fees, even in testing. The MultiStream protocol’s high throughput (1M+ TPS) absorbs spam attempts, while validator slashing deters malicious flooding. Testnet data shows resilience during 80M transaction spikes.
what type of encryption does somnia use?: Somnia reportedly uses homomorphic encryption for secure data processing in privacy-sensitive dApps (e.g., DeFi or metaverse). This allows computations on encrypted data without decryption, though implementation details are sparse and await mainnet confirmation.
what is somnia builder?: Somnia Builder is a low-code platform with drag-and-drop interfaces and pre-built templates for dApps in gaming, NFTs, and DeFi. It abstracts EVM complexity, enabling non-coders to deploy smart contracts via visual workflows, with SDKs for advanced customization.
what are the limitations of somnia's omn: Somnia’s omnichain protocol enables asset transfers across EVM and non-EVM chains, but it’s limited by bridge security risks and latency in cross-chain finality. Testnet supports basic asset bridging; mainnet will expand compatibility but may face scaling challenges.
how does somnia's slashing mechanism wor: Validators stake SOM tokens and face slashing for downtime, double-signing, or malicious behavior. Penalties deduct a percentage of staked tokens (exact rates undisclosed), enforced by the MultiStream consensus to ensure validator accountability and network stability.
what metrics does somnia's testnet dashb: Somnia’s testnet dashboard tracks TPS, transaction volume (e.g., 3.6M total), unique addresses (300K+), validator uptime, and dApp activity (e.g., Chunked’s 80M daily txns). Real-time analytics help developers monitor performance and stress-test results.
how does somnia support real-time gaming: Somnia’s sub-second finality and 1M+ TPS enable real-time gaming via MultiStream’s parallel data processing. Games like Chunked leverage this for seamless multiplayer interactions, with low gas fees (<$0.01) ensuring cost-effective microtransactions.
what is the process for third party vali: Third-party validators apply via Somnia’s governance portal (post-mainnet), staking SOM tokens and meeting hardware specs. Testnet includes external validators for testing, with a vetting process to ensure geographic diversity and reliability.
what is the token supply of $somi?:

what is cuthbert?:
Cuthbert is a separate implementation of Somnia's execution and database, using third party libraries, and without optimisations. Each transaction is run through both Somnia and Cuthbert by the validators, and voting or executiopn is stopped if they ever detect a divergence between the two. This means that if the Somnia client has a bug or an issue in its execution or database, that bug would also have to be present in the separate Cuthbert implementation if this bug were to go undetected. 
 Note: Cuthbert will eventually be phased out of Somnia as the system becomes more mature.
what is the unlock schedule of the $somi:
The $SOMI token has a multi-year vesting schedule for all initial holders including the community. The team, investors, advisors, and launch partners also have a cliff of 12 months during which they cannot transfer their tokens. The detailed schedule can be viewed here: 
 https://docs.somnia.network/concepts/tokenomics/allocation-and-unlocks
how is the somnia token governance?:
The Somnia governance system has 5 different groups: 
Token house - Token owners that primarily govern allocation of foundation and community tokens 
Validator council - Validators in control of hard forks, gas economics and network upgrades. 
 Developer council - Key developers that oversee the technology roadmap 
 User assembly - Key users who are used as a check and balance to other groups 
 Foundation board - Initially in control of the treasury and deployment of new code to the network. Eventually used as a conduit for the other participants and emergency overrides. 
 https://docs.somnia.network/concepts/tokenomics/tokens-governance
